column1: #Text=[0649] The function of G652 was also studied using transgenic plants in which the gene was expressed under the control of the 35S promoter.
#Text=Overexpression of G652 resulted in plants that were small and slow developing.
#Text=Many plants died at an early stage of growth.
#Text=The two lines that were morphologically examined in the T2 generation were small and showed premature senescence of rosette leaves.
#Text=[0650] G652 could be used to manipulate seed tocopherol composition and seed structure and to alter glucosinolate composition in leaves.
#Text=Tocopherols have anti-oxidant and vitamin E activity.
#Text=Increases or decreases in specific glucosinolates or total glucosinolate content might be desirable depending upon the particular application.
#Text=For example: (1) Glucosinolates are undesirable components of the oilseeds used in animal feed, since they produce toxic effects.

#Text=Low-glucosinolate varieties of canola have been developed to combat this problem. (2) Some glucosinolates have anti-cancer activity; thus, increasing the levels of composition of these compounds might be of interest from a nutraceutical standpoint. (3) Glucosinolates form part of a plants natural defense against insects.
#Text=Modification of glucosinolate composition or quantity could therefore afford increased protection from predators.

#Text=Furthermore, in edible crops, tissue specific promoters might be used to ensure that these compounds accumulate specifically in tissues, such as the epidermis, which are not taken for consumption.
#Text=[0651] Based on the overexpression data, G652 could be used to manipulate plant growth and development.
#Text=In particular, the accelerated senescence of the 35S::G652 lines indicates that the gene could be used to modify disease responses, or alter the rate of senescence in crops.
